titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: We finished reading the account of D

Strachey's "Eminent Victorians". The genius for belittlement which marks this writer's work is more apparent here than in the other biographical sketches. He never even attempts to place Arnold in his temporal "setting", and his suggestions everywhere imply the application of the standards of 1918 to a career which had ended before the first half of the last century had run out. I called successively on Lilley, and James, with respect to divers business matters, mostly unpleasing.
has accepted Bredwardine. I hope this will turn out well.
A long & hysterical letter from the female churchwarden
rather suggests trouble in that quarter. I motored to
, and there confirmed 14 candidates. The Vicar,

, bears no good reputation. Bickering with his parishioners, & the non–payment of his debts, are alleged against him. He is an unimpressive little man, speaking indistinctly for lack of front teeth, & seeming to make apology for his own existence. We called on Admiral
Cuthbert. I received a telegram from
, saying that he had reached home, but had to go off again on Saturday. So there is little probability of my seeing him.

The news from France continues to be good. Indeed there seems to be reason for thinking that the German offensive has already been brought to a standstill. The Americans have fought admirably. It is reported tonight that
, the ex–President's youngest son has been killed at the front.
